assetIdentification.assetDescription: Control vehicle door locks through IVI system

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that door lock control commands cannot be maliciously modified or spoofed
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Prevent unauthorized entities from manipulating door lock state

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that door lock control functionality remains available to legitimate users
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Maintain door security functionality during vehicle operation

damageScenarios.title: Unauthorized Door Unlock
damageScenarios.description: An attacker causes unauthorized unlocking of vehicle doors through spoofing, replay, or other manipulation of the door control system

impactAreas.description: Unauthorized door unlocking could allow access to the vehicle while in motion, potentially resulting in passenger ejection or distraction to the driver causing an accident

safetyAspects.hazardDescription: Unexpected unlocking of doors while vehicle is in motion

impactAreas.description: Unauthorized vehicle access can lead to theft of the vehicle or valuables within, with estimated losses exceeding $30,000 per incident on average

directLosses.description: Average market value of stolen vehicle

indirectLosses.description: Brand damage, legal costs, and insurance premium increases

mitigationCosts.description: Cost to redesign and implement secure door locking system across fleet

impactAreas.description: Degraded trust in vehicle security systems requiring escalated user awareness and potential manual verification of door lock status

operationalAspects.userExperience: Degraded - requires manual verification of door locks

impactAreas.description: Limited privacy impact as no personal data is directly exposed, though physical access to the vehicle could allow access to user data stored in infotainment systems

privacyAspects.regulatoryImpact: Potential GDPR concerns if personal data in vehicle is accessed

impactAreas.description: Media coverage of security vulnerabilities in vehicle access systems can significantly damage brand perception and customer trust

reputationAspects.marketImpact: Potential 5-10% decrease in sales following public disclosure

overallImpactRating.justification: Safety-critical impact combined with high financial and reputational damage results in an overall High impact rating per the SAHARA method

damageScenarios.title: Replay of Door Lock Commands
damageScenarios.description: An attacker captures legitimate door lock/unlock commands and replays them at a later time to gain unauthorized access to the vehicle

impactAreas.description: Limited safety concerns as replay attacks typically occur when vehicle is parked, not during operation
Similar to unauthorized door unlock, potential for vehicle theft or theft of items from within the vehicle

directLosses.description: Average market value of stolen vehicle

indirectLosses.description: Legal costs and insurance premium increases

mitigationCosts.description: Cost to implement replay protection in door lock control system

impactAreas.description: Limited operational impact as system continues to function normally
Limited privacy impact as no personal data is directly exposed, though physical access to the vehicle could allow access to user data stored in infotainment systems

privacyAspects.regulatoryImpact: Potential GDPR concerns if personal data in vehicle is accessed

impactAreas.description: Replay attacks are well-understood vulnerabilities that may generate negative publicity but are less sensational than other attacks

reputationAspects.marketImpact: Potential 2-5% decrease in sales following public disclosure

overallImpactRating.justification: High financial impact combined with medium reputational damage but low safety impact results in an overall Medium impact rating per the SAHARA method

damageScenarios.title: Denial of Service on Door Lock Control
damageScenarios.description: An attacker floods the CAN bus with messages that prevent legitimate door lock/unlock commands from being processed, preventing users from controlling door locks

impactAreas.description: Limited safety concerns as doors typically remain in their last state (usually locked) during DoS, potentially preventing emergency exit but also preventing unauthorized entry

safetyAspects.hazardDescription: Unable to unlock doors in emergency situation

impactAreas.description: Limited financial impact as the attack does not directly enable theft or damage

directLosses.description: Potential service visits to reset systems

mitigationCosts.description: Cost to implement DoS protection in CAN communication

impactAreas.description: Significant operational impact as drivers cannot control door locks, potentially preventing entry/exit from vehicle

operationalAspects.serviceInterruption: Complete loss of door lock control functionality
operationalAspects.userExperience: Severely degraded - requires manual key override

impactAreas.description: No privacy impact as DoS does not expose or compromise data
Customer frustration with non-functioning door locks could generate negative reviews and social media coverage

reputationAspects.marketImpact: Potential 1-3% decrease in customer satisfaction metrics
reputationAspects.brandValue: Minimal impact on overall brand value

overallImpactRating.justification: High operational impact combined with medium reputational damage and low safety impact results in an overall Medium impact rating per the SAHARA method

relatedRequirements.description: The door locking system shall maintain door security even in the presence of malformed CAN messages
The door locking system shall complete a lock/unlock command within 500ms of user initiation under normal operating conditions
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Ensure availability of door security functions

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall verify the integrity of door lock/unlock commands before execution
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Prevent tampering with door lock commands

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall require authentication for door lock/unlock commands from the IVI interface

keyTerms.Damage Scenario: Description of potential negative consequences from a cybersecurity event
keyTerms.Impact Analysis: Assessment of damage scenarios resulting from cybersecurity attacks
keyTerms.Replay Attack: Attack where valid data transmission is maliciously repeated

contentSummary: Impact analysis for Door Lock Control Interface addressing three key damage scenarios: unauthorized door unlock (DA-DOOR-01), replay attacks on door commands (DA-DOOR-02), and denial of service on door lock control (DA-DOOR-03). For each scenario, impacts are assessed across safety, financial, operational, privacy, and reputational dimensions. Overall impact ratings are HIGH for unauthorized door unlock and MEDIUM for replay attacks and denial of service. These impact ratings inform subsequent risk assessment and cybersecurity control requirements.
